awd_abstract_narration:
Nontechnical:
The late Paleozoic ice age (LPIA) was the longest, most widespread glacial interval on Earth after complex, multicellular organisms evolved. Despite the significance of this time interval for understanding contemporary global change, it is understudied in non-tropical regions of Pangea. It is of fundamental importance to establish a deep-time perspective on changing paleoecosystems to predict future perturbations in global systems. We will train future Earth scientists in hypothesis-driven, field-based research in Argentina. The scientific research objectives will be met using fossils, sedimentary rocks, and the geochemistry of these rocks and fossils. Outreach activities aimed at increasing the participation of traditionally underrepresented groups in the Geosciences form the core of the broader impacts of the project. 

Technical:
We proposed a multi-faceted program of research and student mentorship on late Paleozoic ice age (LPIA) paleoecosystems. The LPIA is regarded as the best pre-Quaternary analogue for contemporary global change. Despite the significance of this time interval in the climate history of Earth, our understanding of the response of marine and terrestrial ecosystems to late Paleozoic climate and environmental change remains poorly understood. Our multidisciplinary research will include paleoecological, geochemical, and stratigraphic analyses on extensively preserved floral and faunal fossils in southern and western Argentina. To recruit a broader cross section of the diverse SE Wisconsin area to the Geosciences, our rigorous recruitment and training strategy involves new outreach programs created by the PIs and leveraging existing multi-institutional collaborations. Different cohorts of undergraduate and graduate students will travel with the PIs to Argentina for up to 4 weeks each year to conduct research on paleoclimatic and paleoecologic change during the LPIA. Respected Argentinian specialists will provide expertise on different aspects of LPIA paleoecosystems, including biostratigraphy.
org_div_long_name: Office of International Science and Engineering

por.por_cntn:
The main goals of this project were to increase participation of traditionally underrepresented groups in the Geosciences at the University of Wisconsin Milwaukee and to determine patterns of ecosystem and environmental change along the western margin of Gondwana during the Late Paleozoic Ice Age (LPIA).

This project involved 15 students in an international cutting-edge field geology research project while promoting scientific and cultural exchange of ideas between USA and Argentine students and scientists. Participation of the various individuals were spread over 4 field seasons. Of the students, 13 were from the USA (12 UWM and 1 SMU) and 2 from Argentina. 9 students self-identified as women and 6 as men. 9 students were first generation college students, 1 identified as Latino (not counting the 2 Argentine students), and 1 identified as Native American. 9 students graduated with BS Geoscience degrees, 6 of which went on to M.S. programs including 2 who continued graduate studies at UWM (2 M.S. and 1 Ph.D.) on topics covered by this project. 4 students who worked on this grant graduated with MS degrees.  7 students (5 USA and 2 Argentine) worked on some aspect of this project during their Ph.D. projects (4 UWM, 1 SMU, and 2 Argentine students), 5 of which graduated and 2 are still in progress.

Margaret Fraiser served as PI on the project in year 1 before accepting a program manager position at the National Science Foundation forcing her to step away from the project. Co-PI Erik Gulbranson served as PI in year 2 and 3 before he left the University. Co-PI John Isbell served as PI on the grant for the last 3 years, 2 of which saw reduced activity due to the Covid 19 pandemic.  

Scientifically, we investigated glaciomarine and post-glacial strata in the Tepuel Basin of Patagonia and the Calingasta-Uspallata and Paganzo basins in western Argentina to understand deep time glaciation and the post-glacial transition from icehouse to greenhouse conditions following the LPIA. Strata and fossils in the Tepuel Basin were deposited in glaciomarine settings within the South Polar Circle during the Carboniferous and Permian. These strata are characterized by thick shale successions deposited as distal shelf and slope deposits that, through time, built up shallow water platforms (relative sea level highstands) across which wave-dominated deltas and shorefaces prograded to the shelf edge during drops in relative sea level (forced regressions). Drops in relative sea level likely coincided with growth of Gondwanan ice sheets. The shallow shelf deposits were then truncated by glaciers that advance to the shelf edge depositing subglacial and glaciomarine strata. Glacigenic strata were deposited beyond the shelf edge by debris flows and mass transport processes, which built up trough mouth fans on the basin slope and basin floor. Fossils of the Levipustala Faunal Zone indicate that glacial maximum occurred during the Serpukhovian-Bashkirian stage of the Carboniferous. Examined fossil horizons indicate that ice distal paleocommunities contained higher taxonomic diversity and larger body sizes than those in ice proximal settings suggesting that the proximity to glaciers and associated changes in salinity and sedimentation affected marine invertebrate paleoecology. Cold climatic conditions continued in the Tepuel Basin until the Early Permian.

Early ideas suggest that western Argentina was covered by an ice sheet that extended across South America. This idea was from interpretations of a paleovalley in the eastern Paganzo Basin that was identified as a paleofjord. Our investigations indicate that this valley formed from strike-slip motion and that the valley was not carved by glacial ice and contains no signatures of a glacial origin or deposition.  However, Paleovalleys cut into uplifts in the western Paganzo Basin and in the Protoprecordillera, an ancient mountain range that separated the Paganzo Basin from the Calingasta-Uspallata Basin to the west, contain abundant evidence of glacial erosion and deposition. These glaciers formed as valley glaciers or outlet glacier draining ice fields and ice cap that covered uplands along the western margin of Gondwana. Paleogeographically, this area was in the mid to high southern latitudes. Peak glaciation also occurred here during deposition of the Levipustala Faunal Zone, which was substantiated by dating volcanic zircons contained in ash beds. Evidence suggests terminal deglaciation in the Bashkirian (~319 Ma), which resulted from a westward shift in subduction along the continental margin, formation of a magmatic arc, collapse of the Protoprecordillera, and expansion of the precipitation shadow due to uplift of the arc. Disappearance of glaciers here started a stepwise diachronous deglaciation across Gondwana that finally ended in eastern Australia during the Late Permian. The importance of local controls in terminating glaciation in western Argentina in combination with the diachronous nature of deglaciation across the rest of Gondwana indicate that the transition from icehouse to greenhouse conditions during the LPIA was driven by a combination of local, regional, and global drivers.


Last Modified: 01/01/2023
Modified by: John L Isbell
